In the 1940s and 1950s he performed with his wife as "Mattie & Salty." His wife became better known later as Jean Chapel.

name: Woody Shaw
comments: Jazz trumpet, cornet and flugelhorn player.  Shaw was also a composer and leader.  He is sometimes referred to as the "last innovator" on the trumpet, playing free jazz and hard bop influenced by modal jazz.  Shaw had a troubled relationship with heroin, and, according to sources used by SHS, he contracted AIDS from an infected needle at some point in the early 1980s, although the Estate of Woody Shaw denies that the trumpeter had AIDS.  In 1989, Shaw fell in the path of a subway train in Brooklyn, losing his left arm.  Shaw died from complications relating to the fall and his overall medical condition.

In addition to country music, Hank played jazz guitar and was influenced by Wes Montgomery. Hank, in turned, inspired George Benson. Hank's tragic life was the subject of the motion picture, "Crazy."

comments: Radio pioneer Martin Block's Make Believe Ballroom radio show began in February 1935 and started his career as the first disc jockey in New York. In fact, the term disc jockey was originally created to describe Block. Martin Block hosted this show on WNEW for almost 20 years. He was also a songwriter and publisher.

name: Fritz Löhner-Beda
comments: Librettist, lyricist and writer, whose songs remain popular today. In the 1920s he became one of the most sought-after librettists and lyricists in Vienna working with composers like Franz Lehár and Paul Abraham. Almost immediately after the Anschluss (the annexation of Austria by Nazi Germany, in mid-March 1938) he was arrested and deported to the Dachau concentration camp and later that year  transferred to Buchenwald. In December 1942 he was murdered in Auschwitz III Monowitz, where he was beaten to death.

This hymn was simultaneously recorded in a German and an English version. And it was also simultaniously recorded by Ben Cramer in a German and English version, also for the Metronome-label. All versions were produced by Blum.
